summary: The research evaluates statewide initiatives aimed at addressing the shortages of registered nurses and nursing faculty, funded by a portion of hospital-based revenue. Over a four-year period from 2016 to 2020, $90 million was allocated to support 24 nursing programs through competitive grants, which facilitated the preparation and advancement of 532 faculty members. The outcomes of these initiatives were significant, showing a 73% increase in the number of doctoral degrees conferred and the addition of 162 full-time and 190 part-time faculty to the workforce, demonstrating the effectiveness of the funding in resolving the identified shortages.
